comment: This position is known as the Center Counter, or Scandinavian defense. While objectively sound for black, I don't recommend it as this early queen sortie, as it doesn't help black's central control much, plus black always has to be careful where he moves his queen again, as the monarch is always pushed around by White with an eventual Nc3 or c4. If black isn't careful, he could lose his queen easily, as this game demonstrates.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake by highlighting the downsides of the queen's early move, which disrupts the control of the center and leaves the queen vulnerable, as demonstrated in the referenced game.
context: This is a game between W16 (as White) and B16 (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Queen takes on d5
reformulated: The move by Black to place their queen on d5 may seem aggressive but doesn't significantly improve their control over the center. White can easily exploit this by developing pieces like Nc3 or c4, which can put pressure on Black's queen and limit its potential moves, leading to possible vulnerabilities.
